explanation: The second law of thermodynamics, expressed through the Clausius inequality, states that the integral of heat flow divided by temperature over any closed cycle is non-positive. This leads to the definition of entropy as a state function whose total change in an isolated system is always non-negative. The law establishes the arrow of time and explains why certain processes are irreversible in nature.

definitions.definition: Infinitesimal amount of heat absorbed by the system.
Absolute temperature of the heat reservoir.

assumptions.text: The system undergoes a thermodynamic cycle (returns to initial state).
Temperature `T` is the absolute temperature of the heat reservoir.
Heat exchange `dQ` represents heat absorbed by the system from the reservoir.
The equality holds for reversible processes, inequality for irreversible ones.
No heat engine can be more efficient than a reversible Carnot engine operating between the same temperatures.
The system can be connected to arbitrary combinations of heat reservoirs.
Entropy is a state function, so its integral over a closed cycle is zero.
The analysis can be extended from two-reservoir cycles to arbitrary cycles.

derivation.description: Start with the efficiency of a Carnot engine operating between two temperatures.
Any real engine has efficiency less than or equal to the Carnot efficiency.
Express this constraint in terms of work and heat input.
Use the first law to relate work to heat absorbed and rejected.
Substitute the first law relation into the efficiency constraint.
Rearrange to get the fundamental relation between heat flows and temperatures.
Rewrite using the sign convention where `Q_c` is negative (heat rejected).
Express for infinitesimal heat transfers in a two-reservoir cycle.
Generalize to cycles involving multiple heat reservoirs.
Take the continuum limit to get the Clausius inequality.
Decompose the integral by adding and subtracting the entropy change.
derivation.equation: oint (dQ)/T = oint dS - oint (dQ)/T + oint dS

derivation.description: Use the fact that entropy is a state function (integral over closed cycle is zero).
Rearrange to get the entropy inequality.
Express as the fundamental inequality for entropy change.
